metadata.case_name: Legal Representatives of Late Annantrai P. Pattani v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Late Mr. Annantrai P. Pattani appointed Chief Dewan of Bhavnagar State by Hazur Order dated December 10, 1937.
On January 15, 1948, Maharaja introduced responsible Government, appointed assessee as Chairman of Bhavnagar Durbar Bank with no salary.
By Hazur Order dated January 22, 1948, Maharaja granted monthly pension of Rs. 2,000 to assessee in appreciation of services rendered to Maharaja and State during war and thereafter.
On March 1, 1948, Bhavnagar State merged in United States of Saurashtra; Maharaja ceased to be ruler.
On May 31, 1950, Maharaja directed Messrs. Premchand Roychand Sons to pay Rs. 5 lacs to assessee from Maharaja's account; paid on June 12, 1950.
On December 27, 1950, Maharaja ordered Rs. 5 lacs to be debited to Personal Expense Account as gift to ex-Diwan in consideration of loyal and meritorious services.
On March 10, 1953, Maharaja wrote letter confirming Rs. 5 lacs as gift as token of affection and regard for assessee and family, paid from private moneys.
Rs. 5 lacs assessed as taxable under s.7(1) read with Explanation 2 for assessment year 1951-52 by Income-tax Officer.
Appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dismissed; Tribunal held taxable under s.7(1) Expl.2, relied on Dec 27, 1950 order as contemporaneous.
High Court answered reference against assessee, held falls within s.7(1) Expl.2.
Assessee died during High Court proceedings; legal representatives brought on record.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs. 5 lacs has been properly brought to tax in the hands of the assessee for the assessment year 1951-52 under s.7(1) read with Explanation 2 of the Income-tax Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rs. 5 lacs not within s.7(1) Expl.2 as it was a personal gift in token of affection and regard, not remuneration for past services; pension already granted for services.
Dec 27, 1950 document not contemporaneous (written 6 months after payment, for accounting entry); Tribunal erred in treating it as such and rejecting 1953 letter.
Payment relatable to personal qualities, not services; gap of 2 years after cessation of employment and pension.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Beynon v. Thorpe; Reed v. Seymour; Moorehouse v. Dooland; David Mitchell v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: Rs. 5 lacs relatable to office/services as ex-Dewan, remuneration for past services despite being voluntary gift by former employer.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.7(1) Expl.2 Income-tax Act; P. Krishna Menon v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: Tribunal correctly preferred contemporaneous Dec 27, 1950 order over later 1953 letter; no distinction between Maharaja and State.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal erred in treating Dec 27, 1950 document as contemporaneous; it was for accounting, 6 months after payment. Pension already generous for services.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment was personal gift for personal qualities and esteem, not in lieu of salary.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished P. Krishna Menon: there payments arose from ongoing vocation/teaching as causa causans; here, past services already compensated by pension.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test is whether payment accrues by virtue of office/employment or as personal gift.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent by Hidayatullah J.: Tribunal finding on evidentiary value binding; Dec 1950 order shows remuneration for past services despite 'gift' label; follows Krishna Menon.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Focus on why recipient received it, not donor's motive; Maharaja's words indicate consideration of services.

holdings.text: Rs. 5 lacs not taxable under s.7(1) read with Explanation 2 as personal gift, not profit in lieu of salary or remuneration for past services.

precedents_cited.relevance: Payments as personal gifts moved by remembrance of past services already remunerated, not taxable.
Test: personal gift or remuneration? Testimonial for personal qualities not taxable.
Voluntary payments taxable if by virtue of office/remuneration; personal testimonial/gift not.

precedents_cited.case_name: David Mitchell v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Test: appreciation of personality/character vs. services for extra profit.

precedents_cited.case_name: P. Krishna Menon v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Payments received by virtue of vocation/teaching as remuneration, not mere personal gifts.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s.7(1) Expl.2 applies to profits in lieu of salary from former employer unless solely compensation for loss of employment not remuneration for past services; s.4(3) not referred.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed by majority (Kapur and Shah JJ.); High Court judgment set aside; question referred answered in negative against Commissioner; appellants entitled to costs throughout.
outcome.relief_granted: Rs. 5 lacs not taxable; reference answered against Revenue.

key_quotes.text: "It is nothing but a gift moved by the remembrance of past services already efficiently remunerated as services themselves."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Beynon v. Thorpe, adopted to hold payment as personal gift.

key_quotes.text: "The real question was, is the payment in the nature of a personal gift or is it a remuneration? If the latter, it is subject to the tax if the former, it is not."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test applied from Reed v. Seymour to classify payment.

key_quotes.text: "In consideration of Shri Annantrai P. Pattani the Ex-Diwan of our Bhavnagar State having rendered loyal and meritorious services Rs. 5,00,000 are given to him as gift."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Maharaja's Dec 1950 order, disputed as contemporaneous but key to Tribunal/High Court/ dissent.

key_quotes.text: "The sum of Rs. 5,00,000 was not paid to the assessee in token of appreciation for the services rendered as a Dewan of Bhavnagar State but as a personal gift for the personal qualities of the assessee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
